div.head:
EmblemeEmblem 6. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Sowesow your gold in the white foliated earth.

lg.l: Rusticks their seed to th' fertile earth committ,
When with their harrows they have made it fitt:
The Sophi thus their golden seed due sowe
In foliated earth as white as Snow:
This method well observed, and you'le behold,
As in a glasse, by wheat, your budding gold.

div.head: Discourse 6.
div.ab:
A City sayth plato subsiste not by physician and physician, but by physician and
husbandman, that is, men of divers functions, but here mentions the husbandman
and physician first, because their worke are very conspicuous in the imitation,
emendation, and perfection of nature: for they both take a naturall subject,
in which they attending to art add some certaine things necessary being wanting,
or allso remove those things which are superfluous: soe that the art of both may
(as medicine by Hippocrates) be defined by the addition of defect, and subtract
tion of superfluity: for what dos the husbandman more than add ploughing, ridging
furrowing, harrowing, dunging or manuring, sowing, et. to land left by nature, that
is, commit the increase and good successe to nature, which administreth the heat
of the Sunne, and raine, and multiplyes the seeds by them, and promotes them to
standing corne soon after to be reaped: in the meane time whilst the herbe is
springing the husbandman weeds out thistles and all impediments, gashes
the corne being ripe, takes away things superfluous from it being reaped, namely
straw, chaffe, and such other things: Soe allso a physician (as allso a Chymist in
a different respect) teacheth how to praserve pr√¶sent health to many body, being
wanting to recover it by severall remedyes, takes away the morbificke cause,
cures the disease, assuageth symptoms, abates superfluous blood by opening
a veyne, being wanting restores it by apointing good order of dyet, evacua
ates noxious humors by purgation, and soe imitates, supplyes, and amends
nature a thousand ways by the works of the understanding and art; which
being notorious, Chymicall things are rather to be considered by us: for Chy
mistry doth first declare the operations of agriculture by its secret bounds
and wayes of operating: Husbandmen have land, wherein to sow seed, soe allso
the Chymists: they have dung wherewith to manure their ground, soe
allso these, without which nothing could be done, nor any successe expected:
They have seed, the multiplication of which they desire: if Chymists
had not the like, they would (as Lully sayth) imitate the painter, that
endeavoures to expresse the fate of a certaine man, whome hee had never
seen, nor the image of him: Husbandmen expect raine, and heat of the
Sunne, soe allso doe the Chymists truely administer heat convenient to
their worke, and raine: I need say noe more: X Chymistry is exactly parallell to agriculture, and its deputy,
which in all things expresseth its offices, but under a most absolute alle
gory-----From hence the Ancients pro=
duces Ceres, Triptolemus, Osiris, Dionysus, the golden Gods, as relating to Chy=
mistry, teaching as it were men how to cast the seeds of fruits into their
earth, showing tillage, with the propagation of vines, and use of wine,
all which things the ignorant have interpreted to rusticall operations, but
erroneously: for those things, which are absconded from the vulgar, and
declares to the Learned under these veils of agriculture, are most abstruse
mysteryes of nature: To this end say the philosophers that their gold must
be sowed upon white foliated earth, as if they meant that the sowing of corne
should be observed and imitated for example, which the author of the trea=
tise of corne and Jodoc. Greverus have most excellently performed in their
descriptions, for they have both most elegantly accomodated every operation of
agriculture in the producing of corne to the semination of gold, or generation of

the hincture: White earth, because sandy, yields little fruit to the countrymen, by
whome that which is blacke and fatt is more desired, but the white principally
conduceth to the philosophers, if it be foliated, that is well praepared, because
they know how to enrich it with their dung, the other not at all: Now sowing is
the propagation of the world, whereby that, which cannot long endure in an
individuall, is caused to persist in the species: This is in man, animalls, and
plants, in these hermaphroditically, in them under two distinct sexes: but in
metalls farre otherwise: for in them a line is made of the flux of a point, a
superficies of the flux of a line, a body of the flux of a superficies: But
the starrs produced that point before the line, superficies, and body, because
it is the principle of them all: Nature added the flux a long time after, that is,
the caelestiall Sunne did in the earth generate a Sonne, whome Mercury comitted
to Vulcan and Chiron to be educated, that is, to manuall artifice, to be instructed,
even as they write of Achilles, who was held and hardened in fire by his mother
Thetys: hee, amongst other things, Learned Musicke, and the art of playing on the For this reason sayth

Harp from Chiron: but Achilles being noe other than the philosphicall subject (
whose Sonne was was pyrrhus with red haire, without which two Troy could not be
taken and subdued, as wee have abundantly demonstrated in our Hieroglyphicks
booke 6.) therefore doe wee not without reason touch (though cursorily) upon Musicke
in this our worke, where wee describe Achilles, and his heroicke virtues and en=
terprises: For if Musicke adorned soe great a Heroe, why may it not allso
make this our worke more complete and acceptable: For the Angells sing (as the
sacred scriptures attest), the heavens sing, as Pythagoras affirmes, and, as the
Psalmist sayth, declare the glory of God, the Muses and Apollo sing, as
the poett, men even infants sing, birds sing, sheep and geese sing in
musicall instruments, if therefore wee allso sing, there is reason for it
